awd_titl_txt: Convergence: RAISE: Auto-regulatory Scaffolds for Directed Evolution of  Non-living Functional Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a new approach to identify and realize new functional materials under realistic conditions. The method is directed evolution of non-living materials based on auto-regulatory scaffold hosts. The method is bio-inspired. It mimics the approach observed in living things. The research involves developing a platform which incorporates synthesis, screening and feedback, by design, and offers a practical pathway to materials discovery. This strategy overcomes the limitations of screening materials via computer simulations only. The project builds on the convergence of different research areas such as tissue engineering, systems biology, scalable nanomanufacturing and machine learning. The discovery of new materials leads to new functionalities, which leads to new devices and systems, which leads to new products, which benefits society and economy and enhances the nation's prosperity and security. The project demonstrates a paradigm shift in materials discovery and invention. Education plans involve training graduate students and postdocs in convergence approaches to materials screening and discovery, design and realization of auto-regulatory scaffolds and machine learning. Outreach plans are to develop programs such as dissemination through public lectures, integration of research results into new undergraduate courses, and publication of perspectives that combine convergence of research from different fields.

The project's approach is to screen materials through the auto-regulatory interaction of sensors, regulators and known and unknown materials.  These components are located on scaffolds, which are tissue engineering-inspired constructs, whose dimensions are convenient for the developed fabrication and synthesis tools and which may be adapted to a wide range of node materials that include hydrogels, polymers, nanomaterials, and biomaterials. The auto-regulatory aspects of the research involve humidity and photothermal energy sources, among others. The auto-regulatory processes are based on interference effects, thermal expansion, chemical reactions, and cellular response and motion for which the project develops theory and modeling. One benefit of the evolutionary platform is that it interfaces seamlessly with seemingly incompatible combinations of materials such as hydrogels and semiconducting nanomaterials or biological cells and inorganic materials. Materials screening is coupled with machine learning methods for prediction of new materials, which can be extended to other user-defined outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
A biological system can respond spontaneously to external stimuli by evolving biomolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids. However, it has proven difficult to reproduce this behavior in synthetic systems. In this project, we have demonstrated several multifunctional materials that are self-regulating or adaptable. 

We developed a self-regulatory platform that can display tunable feedback cycle timescales. The wrinkle patterns on polyacrylamide hydrogels were designed to flatten and re-form when moist, which directly affected their light scattering properties. By modulating the optical response of the hydrogel wrinkles, the plasmonic nanoparticle (NP) lattices could absorb light and alter the photothermal response of the system. This hybrid materials system allows tunable control of the photothermal effect to determine the regulation cycle time. Next, we developed a hybrid materials platform that auto-regulates the resonance wavelength of plasmonic nanoparticles in response to solvent-induced changes in their surrounding dielectric environment. By adjusting the lattice spacing of the NP arrays, the hydrogel component can act as a sensor for index changes induced by varying solvent compositions. By increasing the NP lattice spacing, the hydrogel matrix expanded to counteract the wavelength decrease.

Additionally, we demonstrated an electrically regulated platform to modulate biological processes in vitro, including cardiomyocyte (CM) modulation, ex vivo stimulation of isolated retinal and heart tissues, and in vivo stimulation of sciatic nerves. We developed a micelle-enabled self-assembly process to fabricate carbon-based micro-supercapacitors that are flexible enough to wrap around biological tissue. Our experiments demonstrated that cells interfaced with electrodes were capable of receiving an electrical signal to regulate their cellular responses, for example, synchronizing their beating.

In addition, we demonstrated artificial soil composites that responded to optical, chemical, and mechanical stimuli. By ice-templating, starch granules, nanoclays, and liquid metal were first prepared as a periodically layered structure and then compressed into a porous matrix. Initially, the matrix was insulating, but it was capable of being converted into arbitrary conductive patterns when triggered mechanically or by lasers. We demonstrated that this soil-like material could enhance microbial metabolism and biofuel production in vitro. The material can also enrich gut bacteria diversity under a pathological condition and rectify bacterial dysbiosis in vivo.

Furthermore, we demonstrate that a dynamic hydrogel composite is capable of mimicking the natural release of cells. Through a monolithic-to-focal morphing process, the composite can exploit both the properties and functions of monolithic and focal biointerfaces. In the hydrogel composites, gelatin is used as the hydrogel matrix, which allows the composite to respond to biological environments while also enabling the macroscopic shaping and manipulation of the material. The hydrogel composite also contains cellular-scale releasable granules that can form focal bio-adhesions in vivo and ex vivo, and degrade at the end for therapeutic benefit.

Finally, we performed both static and time-dependent simulations to determine the adaptable functions for diverse systems. By using thermal and mechanical analysis, we improved the accuracy of our previous model in the study of humidity-sensitive hydrogels. By controlling the heat flux in plasmonic NP arrays, wrinkle formation can be tuned. In addition, viscoelasticity was used to investigate strain-rate sensitivity in wrinkle formation. Furthermore, we examined the stress and strain distributions in hydrogel composites under different uniaxial compressions.

We have published several papers during the support period, including papers in Small, ACS Applied Nano Materials, Nature Nanotechnology, and Nature Chemistry.

Graduate students and undergraduate students were trained to conduct fundamental research on adaptable biomaterials. Students have presented their research in local or national meetings, and received awards and honors. For example, a student working on the biological modulation studies, Bernadette Miao, has been selected for (1) the Goldwater Scholarship, (2) the Illinois Chemical Education Foundation Undergraduate Scholarship, (3) the Stamps Scholarship, and (4) the Student Marshal Scholarship.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2022
Modified by: Bozhi Tian
